Math_Problem: We randomly choose a function $f:[n] \rightarrow[n]$, out of the $n^{n}$ possible functions. We also choose an integer $a$ uniformly at random from $[n]$. Find the probability that there exist positive integers $b, c \geq 1$ such that $f^{b}(1)=a$ and $f^{c}(a)=1$. $\left(f^{k}(x)\right.$ denotes the result of applying $f$ to $x$ $k$ times). Instead of determining the probability that the randomly selected $a$ lies in the same cycle as the fixed starting point $1$ in the functional graph of the random function, simply find $k = p_1 + 2$, where $p_1$ is the initial avoidance factor representing the likelihood of no prior distinct iterates before immediate potential closure to $1$, derived from the step-by-step construction of the cycle length distribution containing $1$. How many functions $f:\{0,1\}^{k} \rightarrow\{0,1\}$ satisfy the property that, for all ordered $k$-tuples $\left(a_{1}, a_{2}, \dots, a_{k}\right)$ and $\left(b_{1}, b_{2}, \dots, b_{k}\right)$ such that $a_{i} \geq b_{i}$ for all $i$, $f\left(a_{1}, a_{2}, \dots, a_{k}\right) \geq f\left(b_{1}, b_{2}, \dots, b_{k}\right)$?

Connecting_Sentence.A1180: Instead of determining the probability that the randomly selected $a$ lies in the same cycle as the fixed starting point $1$ in the functional graph of the random function, simply find $k = p_1 + 2$, where $p_1$ is the initial avoidance factor representing the likelihood of no prior distinct iterates before immediate potential closure to $1$, derived from the step-by-step construction of the cycle length distribution containing $1$.

Synthesised_By.A1180: We randomly choose a function $f:[n] \rightarrow[n]$, out of the $n^{n}$ possible functions. We also choose an integer $a$ uniformly at random from $[n]$. Find the probability that there exist positive integers $b, c \geq 1$ such that $f^{b}(1)=a$ and $f^{c}(a)=1$. $\left(f^{k}(x)\right.$ denotes the result of applying $f$ to $x k$ times). Instead of determining the probability that the randomly selected $a$ lies in the same cycle as the fixed starting point $1$ in the functional graph of the random function, simply find $k = p_1 + 2$, where $p_1$ is the initial avoidance factor representing the likelihood of no prior distinct iterates before immediate potential closure to $1$, derived from the step-by-step construction of the cycle length distribution containing $1$.

Synthesised_By.A1847: How many functions $f:\{0,1\}^{3} \rightarrow\{0,1\}$ satisfy the property that, for all ordered triples \left(a_{1}, a_{2}, a_{3}\right) and \left(b_{1}, b_{2}, b_{3}\right) such that $a_{i} \geq b_{i}$ for all $i, f\left(a_{1}, a_{2}, a_{3}\right) \geq f\left(b_{1}, b_{2}, b_{3}\right)$?

Original_Problem.A1180: We randomly choose a function $f:[n] \rightarrow[n]$, out of the $n^{n}$ possible functions. We also choose an integer $a$ uniformly at random from $[n]$. Find the probability that there exist positive integers $b, c \geq 1$ such that $f^{b}(1)=a$ and $f^{c}(a)=1$. $\left(f^{k}(x)\right.$ denotes the result of applying $f$ to $x k$ times).

Original_Problem.A1847: How many functions $f:\{0,1\}^{3} \rightarrow\{0,1\}$ satisfy the property that, for all ordered triples \left(a_{1}, a_{2}, a_{3}\right) and \left(b_{1}, b_{2}, b_{3}\right) such that $a_{i} \geq b_{i}$ for all $i, f\left(a_{1}, a_{2}, a_{3}\right) \geq f\left(b_{1}, b_{2}, b_{3}\right)$?

Claims.expr: f uniform random from n^n functions [n] → [n]
event ⇔ 1 and a in same cycle of functional graph of f
N(f) = size of cycle containing 1, or 0 if none
number of a satisfying event = N(f)
P_k = (k / n) Pr(N(f)=k) = k p_k / n^2 ∀ k=1..n
{0,1}^3 with partial order x <= y iff x_i <= y_i forall i=1,2,3
f monotone iff forall x <= y, f(x) <= f(y)
D <= P, E <= P, F <= P
points in L1 are pairwise incomparable
points in L2 are pairwise incomparable
forall x, f(x)=1 => forall y >= x, f(y)=1
monotone f partition into: all 0; f(O)=1 (all 1); min level 1; min level 2; min level 3; N = sum of case counts
for min level 1, all 3 in L1=1, f(O)=0: f(L2)=1 all, f(P)=1, number=1
for min level 1, exactly 2 in L1=1: number=3

for min level 1, exactly 1 in L1=1: number=6
